The Julia programming language

1 day workshop at NUIG Kevin Mattheus Moerman, November 6, 2019

Julia workshop

  • Agenda
  • What to bring?
  • What to install?
  • Other links and education content
  • Organizers
  • Where is the workshop

Agenda

09:30-10:15: Session 1: Introduction
10:15-11:00: Session 2: Data structures and flow control
11:00-11:20: Break
11:20-12:10: Session 3: Types, macros and packages
12:10-13:00: Session 4: Julia internals and distributed computing
13:00-14:00: Lunch (not provided suggested location is the Friars restaurant on campus)
14:00-15:30: Session 5: Plotting, performance tuning and examples
15:30-16:00: Break
16:00-17:00: Session 6: Use case examples

Back to top

What to bring

Please bring the following:

  • Your own laptop
  • An extension cord if you have one handy (the nearest power outlet might not be right at the table)

Back to top

What to install

No specific installation instructions are given for this workshop and the workshop may involve online tutorials which do not require a full installation. Users who are keen to set-up a full installation/environment for Julia can follow the steps below: 1) Download Julia and look at the installation instructions for your platform.
2) Download and install the Atom editor (which will function as the IDE for Julia).
3) Install the Juno package in Atom which helps to set-up Atom to function as the IDE for Julia.

Back to top

Additional links and educational resources

1) The julia learning website features additional training/learning resources.
2) JuliaAcademy offers free introductory courses/tutorials as well.
